questions.question: What are the components of an 'IPv4 Header'?

answer_variants.answer: The IPv4 header contains crucial info like the Version, Header Length, Total Length, TTL, Protocol (like TCP or UDP), and the Source and Destination IP addresses.

An IPv4 header is 20 bytes long minimum. Key fields include Version (4), IHL (Length), Type of Service (QoS), Identification/Flags (for fragmentation), TTL, and the 32-bit Source/Destination addresses.

Variable-length header (min 20 octets). Includes Version (4 bits), IHL (4 bits), DS/ECN (8 bits), Total Length (16 bits), ID (16 bits), Flags/Offset (16 bits), TTL (8 bits), Protocol (8 bits), Checksum (16 bits), and Addressing (64 bits total).
Structure consisting of Version, IHL, TOS, Total Length, ID, Flags, Fragments Offset, TTL, Protocol, Header Checksum, and IP addresses.
It's the 'Label on the Outside of the Package'. It says how big it is, how to handle it, who sent it, and which apartment it's going to.
The metadata attached to every IP packet containing routing and identification details.

The 'Options' field at the end of the header is rarely used in modern networking because it can slow down routers. The most important field for modern throughput is the 'DSCP' (within Type of Service) which helps prioritize voice/video traffic.
It's the digital 'Address Slip' that tells the internet where a piece of data is going and how to get it there.
Header Checksum only covers the header itself, not the data payload. In IPv6, this field was removed entirely to speed up routing, relying on Link-layer and Transport-layer error checking instead.
The technical specification of the control information preceding the payload in an Internet Protocol version 4 packet.

questions.question: Explain the structure of a 'TCP Header'.

answer_variants.answer: A TCP header has Port numbers (Source/Dest), Sequence numbers to keep data in order, Acknowledgments, and 'Flags' like SYN and FIN to manage the connection.

The TCP header is 20 bytes minimum. It includes Source/Destination Ports, a 32-bit Sequence Number, a 32-bit Acknowledgment Number, the Window Size for flow control, and Control Flags (URG, ACK, PSH, RST, SYN, FIN).
Layer 4 PDU header. Fields: Ports (16-bit), Sequence# (32-bit), Ack# (32-bit), Data Offset (4-bit), Control bits (9-bit), Window (16-bit), Checksum (16-bit), Urgent Pointer (16-bit).
Complex header structure facilitating reliable, ordered, and error-checked delivery of a stream of octets.
It's like a 'Certified Mail Receipt'. It has the room numbers (Ports), a page number (Sequence#), a field to sign saying you got the last page (Ack#), and a note saying 'Ready for more' (Window).
The control portion of a TCP segment managing ports, sequencing, and reliability.

The 'Sequence' and 'Acknowledgment' numbers quantify the number of BYTES sent, not the number of packets. This allows TCP to 'acknowledge' exactly where a data stream was interrupted if a connection fails.
It's the set of rules that lets the computer send data piece-by-piece and put it back together perfectly on the other side.

The 9 control bits include ECN (Explicit Congestion Notification) flags (CWR, ECE). PSH (Push) tells the receiver to send the data to the application immediately rather than waiting for a full buffer.
The specification of the control parameters used by the Transmission Control Protocol for managing end-to-end data integrity.
An Ethernet frame has Preamble (to wake up the receiver), Destination MAC, Source MAC, the actual data, and a Checksum at the end to catch errors.
Standard Ethernet II frames consist of a Preamble, Start-of-Frame Delimiter, Destination/Source MAC addresses (6 bytes each), Type field (2 bytes), the Data/Payload, and a Frame Check Sequence (FCS).

answer_variants.technical: IEEE 802.3 standard. Preamble (7 octets), SFD (1 octet), MAC Header (12 octets), EtherType (2 octets), Payload (46-1500 octets), and 32-bit CRC footer.

answer_variants.answer: Layer 2 PDU containing hardware addresses, protocol type, payload, and error-detection CRC code.
It's like a 'Train Car'. The Preamble is the locomotive noise heard from a distance. The MAC addresses are the origin and destination stations. The cargo is the IP packet inside.
The physical-layer framing of data for transmission over regional networking cables.
Ethernet frames have a minimum size of 64 bytes. If the data is too small, 'Padding' is added to fill it out. This ensures collisions can be detected on older, half-duplex shared mediums.
It's the very first part of a message that travels through the physical wire or Wi-Fi.
'Jumbo Frames' extend the standard payload limit from 1500 bytes to 9000 bytes, reducing CPU overhead for high-performance storage networks, though every device in the path must support them.
The data link layer data transmission unit that defines the start and end of a packet on an Ethernet network.

questions.question: What are the common 'ICMP' Message Types?

answer_variants.answer: ICMP is used for troubleshooting. Common types are 'Echo Request' (Ping), 'Echo Reply', 'Destination Unreachable', and 'Time Exceeded'.
ICMP (Internet Control Message Protocol) is used for network diagnostics. Type 8/0 are Ping requests and replies. Type 3 is Destination Unreachable. Type 11 is Time Exceeded (used by traceroute).
Error reporting and operational information protocol. Messages use an 8-bit Type and 8-bit Code. Example: Type 3, Code 1 (Host Unreachable).
Diagnostic protocol messages including Echo, Destination Unreachable, Source Quench, and Redirect.
It's like 'Road Signs' on a highway. A 'Road Closed' sign is a Destination Unreachable. A 'Speed Limit' note is a Source Quench (telling you to slow down).
The reporting system routers use to announce failures and connectivity statuses.

ICMP is unusual because it doesn't use TCP or UDP port numbers. It is encapsulated directly in IP packets. While vital for diagnostics, many firewalls block ICMP 'Echo' to prevent attackers from mapping the network.
It's the internet's way of sending an 'Error Message' when something goes wrong with a connection.
ICMP Redirects (Type 5) are used by routers to tell a host: 'There is a better router for this destination, please send your future packets there instead'.
The set of control messages used by network devices to send error messages and operational information indicating success or failure when communicating.
DHCP is the service that automatically gives your computer an IP address when you plug it into a network, so you don't have to set it up manually.
DHCP uses a four-step process called DORA: Discover, Offer, Request, and Acknowledgment. It automates the assignment of IP addresses, subnet masks, default gateways, and DNS servers.
Application layer protocol running over UDP ports 67 (server) and 68 (client). It manages a pool of IP addresses and leases them to clients for a specific duration.
Automated network configuration protocol utilizing the DORA exchange to provision IP parameters.
It's like 'Checking into a Hotel'. You ask for a room (Discover), they show you an available room (Offer), you say you'll take it (Request), and they hand you the key (Acknowledgment).
A protocol for automatic IP address assignment and network configuration.

DHCP leases are temporary. When a lease is 50% expired, the client attempts to renew it. If it fails, it tries again at 87.5% and finally releases the IP if the lease expires entirely, trying to DISCOVER a new one.
It's like a 'Digital Receptionist' that gives your computer its 'ID Tag' the moment it walks onto a new network.
A 'DHCP Relay Agent' allows a single central DHCP server to provide IP addresses to devices on different subnets by forwarding the broadcast requests as unicast traffic.
A network management protocol used on Internet Protocol (IP) networks for automatically assigning IP addresses and other communication parameters to devices.

questions.question: What is 'IPv6' and what are its key features?

answer_variants.answer: IPv6 is the new version of IP addresses (like `2001:0db8...`) created because we ran out of the old IPv4 numbers.
IPv6 uses 128-bit addresses, providing a massive increase in available IPs ($3.4 \times 10^{38}$). Key features include built-in IPSec support, no need for NAT, and autoconfiguration (SLAAC).
Next-generation IP. Features: Simplified header (8 fields), Hierarchical addressing, Multicast instead of Broadcast, Flow Labeling for QoS, and mandatory Jumbogram support.
128-bit addressing scheme with improved header efficiency, native security, and stateless configuration.
IPv4 is like having a '10-digit phone number' system (too many people, not enough numbers). IPv6 is like every single person on Earth having a billion unique phone numbers each.
The 128-bit protocol replacing IPv4 with massive address space and better routing.

IPv6 removes the 'Header Checksum' to reduce router CPU load and has no 'Fragmentation'—if a packet is too big for a link, the router just tells the sender to resize it. This makes the overall internet backbone much faster.
It's the 'Internet 2.0' address system that makes sure every smart lightbulb and toaster can have its own private address.

IPv6 uses 'Anycast' addresses, where multiple servers can share the same IP. The network will automatically route the user to the closest server (topologically), which is vital for CDNs like Cloudflare.

The most recent version of the Internet Protocol (IP), the communications protocol that provides an identification and location system for computers on networks and routes traffic across the Internet.
FTP has two ways to work: Active (the server connects back to you) and Passive (you connect to the server). Passive is better for modern firewalls.

FTP uses two separate connections: Control (Port 21) and Data (Port 20). In Active mode, the server initiates the data connection. In Passive mode (PASV), the client initiates both, which avoids firewall issues at the client's end.
Dual-channel protocol. Active (PORT): Client listens on N+1, server connects from 20. Passive (PASV): Server listens on random high port, client connects to it. Uses ASCII or Binary data types.
Client-server protocol for file exchange using control and data ports in either Active or Passive configurations.
Active mode is like 'Ordering Pizza' and having the driver come to your door. Passive mode is like the pizza place saying 'Your pizza is ready on Table 4', and you go and pick it up yourself.
File transfer protocol using two modes to handle data port initiation.
FTP is inherently insecure as it sends passwords in plain text. Modern projects should use SFTP (which runs over SSH) or FTPS (FTP over SSL) to encrypt the control and data channels.
It's a very old way for computers to send files to each other, but it's still used today for updating websites.
The 'FXP' (File Exchange Protocol) extension allows two FTP servers to talk to each other directly to transfer files between them, controlled by a client who never actually sees the data.
A standard communication protocol used for the transfer of computer files from a server to a client on a computer network.
The default gateway is the IP address of your router. It's the 'exit door' your computer uses to get out to the internet.

The default gateway is the node that a computer uses to send traffic intended for a destination outside its own local subnet. Without a gateway, a computer can only talk to other devices in its own house or office.
The routing entry (0.0.0.0/0) that points to a specific interface or next-hop IP. Usually the IP address of the local router's internal interface (e.g., 192.168.1.1).
The network node serving as an access point to other networks when no other route is specified.
It's like the 'Main Office' in a school. If you need to send a letter to another school, you don't walk there yourself—you give it to the office and trust them to know how to mail it.
The IP address traffic is sent to when the destination is not local.

When a computer wants to send data, it ANDs the destination IP with its subnet mask. If it doesn't match the local network ID, it attaches the MAC address of the Default Gateway to the packet and sends it there.
It's the bridge that connects your home network to the rest of the world.

Redundancy protocols like HSRP or VRRP allow multiple routers to share a single 'Virtual' Default Gateway IP, so if one router dies, the other takes over instantly with no config change needed on PCs.
The node in a computer network using the Internet Protocol Suite that serves as the forwarding host to other networks when no other route specification matches the destination IP address of a packet.

questions.question: What is 'SMTP' and how does it relate to POP3/IMAP?

answer_variants.answer: SMTP is for SENDING emails. POP3 and IMAP are for RECEIVING emails.

SMTP (Simple Mail Transfer Protocol) is a 'push' protocol used to move messages from a client or server to the destination. POP3/IMAP are 'pull' protocols used by users to download their mail from the destination server.
Text-based protocol over TCP port 25 (or 587). Uses commands like HELO, MAIL FROM, and RCPT TO. Relies on DNS MX records to find the target mail server.
Standard protocol for outgoing mail transmission (SMTP) vs incoming mail access protocols (POP3/IMAP).
SMTP is the 'Mail Truck' that carries your letter to the post office. IMAP is the 'Post Office Box' where you go to read your mail from anywhere in the world.
SMTP sends mail out; IMAP/POP3 fetch mail in.

POP3 usually downloads and deletes mail from the server, while IMAP syncs mail across multiple devices. Modern SMTP almost always requires 'STARTTLS' to encrypt the connection before sending passwords or content.
These are the three 'Gears' that make your email app work: one to send, one to get, and one to sync.
To prevent 'Email Spoofing', SMTP is now supplemented by SPF, DKIM, and DMARC which use DNS to verify that the sender really has permission to use that domain name.
An internet standard for email transmission versus protocols for retrieving email from a remote server.
Port numbers are like 'Room Numbers' in a building. The IP is the building address, and the port tells the data which specific app (like Web, Email, or Games) it belongs to.
Ports allow multiple services to run on a single IP. Well-known ports (0-1023) include HTTP (80), HTTPS (443), SSH (22), and DNS (53). Ephemeral ports are used for client-side connections.
16-bit unsigned integers (0-65535) used by TCP/UDP for multiplexing at the Transport layer. A 'Socket' is defined as the combination of an IP address and a Port number.
Endpoint identifiers in an operating system used for process-to-process communication.
If an IP address is the 'Phone Number' of a company, the Port Number is the 'Extension' (e.g. dial 80 for Sales, 443 for Support).
The application-specific endpoint identification on a networked computer.

Ports are divided into three ranges: Well-known (0-1023), Registered (1024-49151), and Dynamic/Private (49152-65535). Only root/admin users can typically bind an application to a 'Well-known' port to prevent user-level apps from hijacking system services.
It's how your computer keeps your web browsing separate from your Spotify music and your Zoom calls at the same time.
Port 0 is reserved and cannot be used for traffic; however, it is sometimes used in programming to tell the OS to 'pick any available port' for a new listener.
A communication endpoint in an operating system, identified by a 16-bit number, used to map network traffic to specific software processes.
